passage_list.text: Konrad Hartman slept with one eye open. I asked him once why his eye did that. He said one time he was helping Kathleen hang curtains in the front room, and she was up on the ladder with a cigarette in her mouth, like always. In his German accent, as if his thick lips were too relaxed to participate, he explained, “She dropped the hot ash right in my eye. It burnt my eye and now it don’t close.” Then he smiled like it was nothing. But in the scene my mind created, he hollered, smacked the ladder, and Kathleen teetered in the air.

Konrad often came home late at night and slept most of the morning, but not through breakfast because the trailer was so small—the kitchen table where we ate stood just a couple of feet away from him sleeping there on the sofa. So he’d get up and eat with Kathleen and me, leaning on his meaty forearms, drooping forward over his eggs and bacon as if his back was still sleeping. Then he’d return to sleep on the sofa for the rest of the morning. When I’d come through the door from playing outside, I’d see that eye looking all white like it was dead, or sometimes moving like it was searching for something while he slept. When I was six, it was the creepiest thing I’d ever seen.

I asked Konny, which is what I called him, a lot of questions. I talked to him more than to most other adults on account of the hour-long ride from my house in the city to Kathleen and Konny’s trailer in Dennings Orchard Trailer Court. He would come to get me in his big blue Lincoln after his shift managing the pet store. On the drive, we talked about my school, about why bunnies’ noses wiggle, and why somebody chose red, yellow, and green for the traffic lights. We talked about everything. He didn’t seem to mind my talking, and didn’t turn the radio on or say he was too busy, the way other adults did. When Konny stepped on the brake, he always put his arm out to keep me from sliding off the seat.

Kathleen wasn’t really Konny’s wife. My mother called her his “common-law wife,” which I understood to mean they had not stood before a minister or anyone else in charge of such things, but they considered themselves married anyway. Kathleen had probably lived at our house longer than she’d lived in the trailer with Konny. She became my nanny when my baby nurse, Mrs. Tenney, left, around the time I was a year old, and stayed until I turned six. Kathleen made sure I brushed my teeth while I stood on the little stool in the bathroom, put barrettes in my hair, and shined my Mary Jane shoes with Jubilee. She cooked my meals and when she made something special, she let me lick the spoon. At night, Kathleen bathed me, on her knees beside the tub, and blew giant soap bubbles by making an O with her thumb and fingers. When it was time for bedtime stories, she used a magnifying glass because her eyes were so bad that even her Coke-bottle-thick glasses weren’t enough. I thought everyone read that way, and when I started to read by myself, I looked for and used her magnifier. Her lap was the only one I can recall sitting on and it felt doughy-soft and smelled like baby powder. Her long gray hair crossed over her head in two plaits and sometimes she let me put the bobby pins in. Kathleen’s room was off our upstairs hall and had a twin bed, a tall dresser, and a reading chair, which was all that would fit. But when I was six, my parents moved to a new, more modern house where there wasn’t a room for her anymore and she left us to go live with Konny in the trailer.

questions.question: What is the main reason Konrad Hartman sleeps with one eye open?

options.B: He was injured by hot ash from Kathleen's cigarette.
options.C: He is naturally a light sleeper.
options.D: He is afraid of the dark.

questions.explanation: The passage explains that Konrad's eye was injured by hot ash from Kathleen's cigarette, which is why it doesn't close properly.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on the direct explanation provided in the text to identify the main idea.

questions.question: As used in the passage, the phrase 'leaning on his meaty forearms' most likely suggests that Konrad is:
questions.explanation: The phrase 'leaning on his meaty forearms' and the description of him 'drooping forward' suggest that Konrad is still tired and not fully awake.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to descriptive phrases that provide insight into a character's state or emotions.

questions.question: What can be inferred about the narrator's relationship with Konny from the passage?

options.B: The narrator feels a strong emotional connection to Konny.
options.C: The narrator is indifferent to Konny.
options.D: The narrator is jealous of Konny.

questions.explanation: The narrator describes talking to Konny about a wide range of topics and mentions that Konny didn't mind the narrator's talking, which suggests a close and comfortable relationship.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for details that reveal the narrator's feelings and attitudes toward other characters.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the detailed description of Kathleen's actions in the passage?

options.A: To highlight her strictness as a nanny.
options.B: To emphasize her nurturing and caring nature.
options.C: To criticize her lack of professionalism.
options.D: To show her disinterest in the narrator.

questions.explanation: The detailed description of Kathleen's actions, such as bathing the narrator and reading bedtime stories, emphasizes her nurturing and caring nature.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Consider how specific details contribute to the overall portrayal of a character.

questions.question: Which piece of evidence best supports the idea that Kathleen was deeply involved in the narrator's daily life?

options.A: Kathleen made sure I brushed my teeth while I stood on the little stool in the bathroom.
options.B: Kathleen’s room was off our upstairs hall and had a twin bed, a tall dresser, and a reading chair.
options.C: Kathleen had probably lived at our house longer than she’d lived in the trailer with Konny.

questions.explanation: The detail about Kathleen ensuring the narrator brushed their teeth highlights her active role in the narrator's daily routines.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Choose evidence that directly supports the specific claim being made.

questions.question: As used in the passage, the word 'teetered' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: The word 'teetered' suggests an unsteady, wavering movement, which fits the context of Kathleen being on a ladder.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the surrounding context to infer the meaning of unfamiliar or ambiguous words.

questions.question: What can be inferred about the narrator's feelings toward Konrad's sleeping habits?

options.B: The narrator is frightened by them.
options.C: The narrator is indifferent to them.
options.D: The narrator is annoyed by them.

questions.explanation: The narrator describes Konrad's open eye as 'the creepiest thing I’d ever seen,' indicating fear or discomfort.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for descriptive language that reveals the narrator's emotional response.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the passage describing the narrator's conversations with Konny?

options.A: To show Konny's lack of interest in the narrator.
options.B: To highlight the narrator's curiosity and Konny's patience.
options.C: To emphasize the narrator's dislike of long car rides.

questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes the narrator's curiosity and Konny's willingness to engage in conversations, highlighting their bond.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Consider how the interactions between characters reveal their relationship dynamics.

questions.question: What was Kathleen's role in the narrator's early life?
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that Kathleen became the narrator's nanny after the baby nurse left.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify explicit information in the text to answer straightforward questions.

questions.question: How does the narrator's description of Kathleen contrast with their description of their parents?

options.A: Kathleen is described as nurturing, while the parents are described as distant.
options.B: Kathleen is described as strict, while the parents are described as lenient.
options.C: Kathleen is described as indifferent, while the parents are described as overbearing.
options.D: Kathleen is described as unprofessional, while the parents are described as highly skilled.

questions.explanation: The narrator describes Kathleen as nurturing and caring, while the parents are portrayed as distant and surprised by the narrator's presence.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Compare and contrast character descriptions to understand relationships and themes.

scoring_guidelines.800_level_performance: Students scoring at this level demonstrate mastery of all tested skills, including advanced analysis, synthesis, and reasoning. They can infer complex meanings, analyze text structure, and make cross-text connections with precision.
scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with higher-level analysis and synthesis. They can identify main ideas and details but may miss subtle inferences or complex textual relationships.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, often requiring students to infer meaning, analyze complex text structures, or make cross-text connections.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and vocabulary in context, with a focus on understanding main ideas, details, and character relationships.
explanation_summary.easy_questions: Easy questions evaluate basic comprehension and the ability to identify explicit information in the text.
